Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: how to memorize slides even as the professors protest that it is "not a memorization class/quiz/test"
I have learned a lot about Biochemistry. Almost memorized a lot of (unnecessary) facts about biochemistry, as well as a lot of broader concepts about how metabolism works.
I learned about metabolism and the molecules and reactions that go into metabolism
The most important thing I gained from this class was a complete understanding of the essentials of metabolism - the concepts, how the pathways interact with each other, etc.
Biochem
This class taught me about the basics of metabolism and how to understand the molecular interactions happening in the human body.
Basic biochemistry of proteins and carbohydrates, as well as a relatively comprehensive understanding of metabolic pathways and how they are regulated.
This class gives you a pretty reasonable understanding of the essential processes that comprise the human metabolism.
You learn the basics of biochemistry from things like metabolism to protein mechanisms.
I learned how to absolutely grind to memorize heinous amounts of information. I learned about biochemical concepts, particularly metabolism. I learned how to integrate and analyze pathways.
Basically, biochemistry. Proteins and lipids and carbohydrates. Not nucleic acids.
Proteins, lipids, carbohydrates, and metabolism were the big topics covered.

I developed both a broad understanding of fundamental biochemical concepts as well as knowledge of a few detailed examples to illustrate these concepts. I learned about proteins, carbohydrates, and lipids, and how their levels are regulated in metabolism (primarily carbohydrates and lipids).
This course is a lot. Lectures are dense and jam packed with information. But the information is all good stuff and I learned a lot in the process.
general biophysical processes

I feel I have a very strong basis of understanding the main players in any biological context, and how they tend to behave based on kinetics,etc. I also learned about how these are all orchestrated in the larger context of keeping me as a person alive.

Chemistry of amino acids, carbohydrates, lipids
Protein structure, function, folding, enzyme kinetics
Metabolism

I thought this class was very good and very comprehensive. Overall I think I learned exactly what I should have in regards to biochemistry and came away with a general understanding of pretty much everything that was taught.

As expected, I learned a great deal concerning biochemistry - the material was interesting, and we spent the majority of the course discussing proteins and various metabolic pathways. In general, I learned a lot - I think this truly will be useful in the medical profession moving forward.
I learned a lot about biochemical processes, specifically those involving metabolism. I developed little skills I would say, but came out with a ton of factual knowledge.
A lot about proteins and carbs! Very well designed course that provides a broad yet comprehensive overview on biochemical processes.
Metabolism is complicated, but all of the processes also operate on the same principles.
lots of biochem knowledge and metabolism principles
Half a semester of protein biochemistry, and half a semester of metabolism.

I gained a strong foundation in biochemistry that is readily applicable to both daily life and my medical ambitions. I garnered a large amount of information about life and learned how to bridge the "gap" between non-living molecules (first half of the course) and larger, more complex living systems (second half of the course). This course was very well-taught and organized, and I can honestly say that I am excited to apply what I have learned in other settings (both within and outside of MB&B).
I learned how to think like a biochemist, and I also memorized a lot of bio.

I learned a great deal about small, molecular processes, which I thought was very useful. Many biology courses tend to gloss over the mechanisms, but this class definitely emphasized them. I think I would have liked to see a little more organic chemistry thrown in, particularly when we were talking about enzyme activity and affinity and kinetics, but overall, I didn't feel the course lacked much detail.
I learned biochemistry on a detailed and conceptual level. I learned how to solve scientific problems and how to analyze complex biochemical pathways.

Learned standard biochemical techniques and introductory topics, moved onto an in-depth unit of metabolism. The class focuses on biological topics, with a strong chemical and organic chemistry focus of reactions and how things pair. A lot of the class deals with energetic favorability of reactions and how things in our body do what they do.
I learned metabolism pathways as well as other standard biochem.

MBB 300 really brings together many of the prerequisite science and pre-med classes and the key topics that were emphasized by the professors. This is the best into class to gain an understanding of what occurs in metabolism at the macromolecular level.
Fundamentals for understanding the field of biochemistry

It was a good introduction to biochemistry, covering some key pathways and principles that can be applied to many other areas of biochemistry. Helps increase biochemistry literacy so that future reading/lessons are much easier to pick up.
Covers introduction to biochemistry topics about protein structure, enzymes, metabolism, hormonal regulation, etc...
A solid biochemistry foundation and problem solving skills

I feel like I gained a very strong overview of biochemical processes overall, which will definitely be useful to be in the future. However, this course could have been so much more enjoyable than it was and I would highly recommend the MCDB Biochemistry to students who want a fair shot at a decent grade. I feel like the grading in this class was extremely unfair and unpredictable - the exams were definitely doable if you studied a ton but virtually no partial credit was given, and if your answer doesn't exactly conform to the Professors' answer keys, you'll get no credit, even if you present a valid line of reasoning. Likewise, only one question out of the whole pset is graded so if you happen to fail that question but do well on the rest of the pset, you will still end up with a terrible grade. Furthermore, Professor Koelle's much emphasized "this course is not about the details but about the overarching concepts" is totally false. This course is ALL ABOUT DETAILS. You have to memorize every single word of every slide to even have a shot at an ok grade on the exams. People put an inordinate amount of work into this class, which makes the curve very tough; much much worse than most other premed classes. Overall, these grading policies made this course extremely unenjoyable for me as I was constantly worrying about grades, which is a real shame as the material is very exciting.
I learned some of the basic principles behind biochemistry and much of the experimental design and logic that goes into studying biochemistry.
Pretty much everything biochem from looking at the big picture to memorizing the small scale as welel
I developed an in-depth understanding of various biochemical concepts, that which greatly help me in the future.

I learned a lot about biochemistry and different metabolic pathways.  I also learned to think critically and how to integrate these systems, so that I could figure out how changes to one systems will affect other pathways.  Really cool stuff!

I learned about the chemical and physical principles of proteins, and I specifically learned about enzymes and their kinetics and regulation. I learned about metabolism and how different catabolic and anabolic pathways are integrated and regulated. I learned about specific molecular examples of the principles we discussed.

I learned a great deal about the principles of metabolism and how various pathways fit together. I also learned about proteins, lipids, and sugars, and the ways these molecules are built and interact with each other.

Very in depth knowledge of the body's metabolism and also extensive knowledge on protein dynamics and enzyme kinetics. I felt that this was truly an applied science course and allowed me to use the knowledge that I had gathered after taking years of chemistry, biology, and organic chemistry.
I learned how to analyze biological processes on a mechanistic level by applying chemical and physical principles and looking at how different processes interact with one another in metabolism.

I learned about biochemistry of individual molecules and of entire metabolic pathways. I gained insight into the integration of different metabolic pathways used to maintain homeostasis in a living organism, almost all of which were involved in the breakdown or storage of energy.
Lots of memorization of biochemistry principles, pathways, and etc. Some application of that knowledge, but largely regurgitation of facts.

how to critically analyze exam questions
how to connect concepts from many different lectures
how to go through hundreds of slides and come back with a comprehensive understanding of the main ideas
how to study effectively and ineffectively
Biochemistry of major macromolecules (other than nucleic acids), principles of metabolism and details of specific pathways
I learned the detailed processes of metabolism, and further how to synthesize material.
Individual protein structures and their function, individual pathways and their function, metabolism as a whole and how pathways are integrated.

I learned a lot in this course regarding the biosynthesis and degradation of various important molecules of life. Despite the volume of information, I learned to parse through it for the logic behind the mechanisms, which helped my learning and retention of the material.

I learned how to absorb massive amounts of information and spit it back out. I do feel that sometimes this is what must be done to understand biological processes on a deeper level, and thus memorizing things pays off in the end.
I learned the principles of enzyme mechanisms, and a holistic understanding of chemical processed in the body.
I learned about pathways of metabolism and the methods proteins and organic molecules use to perform these pathways.
I learned how health and science overlap on a micro level

I very honestly feel like I did not learn very much other than trying to figure out what I was supposed to know. If the instructors' ambitions are to emphasize principals then they failed. I memorized, memorized, memorized, and that is really what this course is all about.
Body cycles, basic biochemical mechanisms
The course was an introduction course that consisted mostly of memorizing biochemistry facts.

I really disliked that the professor told me that I could submit for a regrade, but that I would likely end up with a lower grade than I started with because they'd look for other mistakes. I think the biggest weakness of this course was that they didn't seem to want their students to do well.

Strengths: great material, Matt Simon
Weaknesses: complete lack of curve made everything insanely high-pressure

Strengths; Great TAs, strong lecturers, well organized, well taught
Weaknesses; Scope of material chosen
There should be 3 midterms rather than a cumulative final. There is way too much information to be able to succeed on a cumulative final.
The professors were amazing and the lectures engaging.
I took it because I had to as a premed student. It's a super difficult class and I'm probably not going to do very well but a lot of it is my fault for not putting in the time that I should have.

This course was organized well and the order in which we learned about the processes helped me to see connections between them. The main concepts we should take away from lectures were well-defined. However, the amount of material can be overwhelming. It was helpful to have study guides which emphasized the details to learn, in addition to the big concepts, but it sometimes did feel like we had to have everything memorized, besides just details in the study guides.

The course is great in that it teaches a lot of content, and integrates it together well.  Additionally, the instructors are both fantastic and always accessible.  However, the course places a HUGE emphasis on exams and seems to focus on knowing all the material at a pretty cursory level in order to do well on these.  This makes the few days before the exam very stressful, but I feel like I engaged minimally with the material outside of these pre-exam periods (weekly homeworks required minimal thought and took ~30 minutes to complete).  It would be nice if the course could introduce some sort of project that is worked on throughout the semester, in which we'd explore a particular area of the material more deeply.

strengths: energetic instructors, in-depth content, good organization of lectures and surprisingly good synthesis of topics at the end

weaknesses: disproportionate difficulty of exam questions to pset questions. Pset questions were so easy that they were almost useless, although I guess the tradeoff is that the weekly pset workload was super low (30min).

Strengths: it's pretty organized and straightforward, a lot of people to go to if you need help

Weaknesses: The way the course evaluates students' knowledge is terrible. The grading is incredibly harsh and seems to take off points despite the answer being clear that the student understood the material for the most part. Points were taken off for missing incredibly specific phrases or words. The learning environment was also incredibly cutthroat and not enjoyable. Everyone is incredibly competitive which made the class extremely unenjoyable to take.

You learn a LOT of material that I imagine will be helpful later, in other courses and with the MCAT. However, it was tragically boring, and the format of the course was poor. PSETs were too easy, and therefore didn't prepare us for the incredibly nit-picky exams. Midterms are worth too much, quizzes not enough.
Extremely structured / organized, with a great deal of satisfactory degree of transparency regarding examinations and grading policies.

Strengths: Material is interesting. Lots of resources to ask questions etc.

Weaknesses: Not a fan of the emphasis of memorization. They SAY it's concept-based but in reality you have to memorize a ton of random facts, and you're screwed over if you don't.

I feel like there was too much memorization of random facts that were needed for the exams. Other than that, the lectures are pretty well organized and I like the fact that they print the handouts for us.

The course was well organized, and the lectures had a sensible arc to them. Concepts were highlighted in numerous different ways, and the examples used illustrated these concepts well. The supplements at the end of lectures were incredibly interesting and it was nice to enjoy a 10-15 minute lecture on a topic on biochemistry without having to worry about knowing every detail on in for a future exam.

The amount of detailed knowledge expected of us made sense given the nature of the field of biochemistry, but the exams seemed to focus a little too heavily on minute details that were shown once on a lecture slide and not even discussed in great detail -- examples I could think of are that heme bH is the carrier that reduces Q(dot) to QH2, and that CN- inhibits complex IV of the electron transport chain.

Too much information, lectures are impossible to get all the way through without feeling exhausted. That being said, the this isn't really the fault of the class but just the nature of this area of chem and bio. The information was presented fairly clearly and the fact that we got power points printed for us each class is a total game changer.
The tests are super hard even if you study for hours and hours

Strengths: I honestly felt that the course was structured very well to build upon foundational understanding of each prior topic. Learning about how atoms act, then about how these larger molecules act, and how they interact with each other in a system, and how those systems modify each other. Very well organized and very strong explanation of every single topic. I honestly didn't NEED the textbook (though it was VERY helpful to fill in the blanks when I may have spaced out during lecture.  

Weakness: Sections seemed pretty irrelevant. I did not ever feel compelled to go and even when I did I felt it was a waste of my time
Section sometimes felt like a regurgitation of the lecture, which wasn't bad, but I felt it could have a been a bit more useful.

The only weakness of this course I would say is that I thought the exams were graded pretty harshly in terms of direct fact recall. I understand you cannot always give partial credit for "almost" answers but I think the exams tended to test rote memorization a little more than conceptual understanding.

Course was well taught, and the printing of the lecture slides was extremely nice and helpful. Overall no immediately clear weakness - I don't really support the grading system, which is based on the median rather than the mean, creating a significantly more competitive environment. (e.g. extreme example, but if first quintile is somehow composed of 100's, an exam score of 99 would be an A-) But the strengths of the class outweigh the grading system (after all, the goal is to do well in the class regardless of how it's graded). I enjoyed the material for the most part, I enjoyed the lecturing, section was useful for the most part, and problem sets were appropriately difficult and spaced.

Strengths include the lecturing styles of the instructors which were clear and well-paced. I also appreciated the instructors connecting different topics together whenever possible. Weaknesses include the need to memorize the most obscure information from slides in some of the midterms.
This class was well-organized and very thorough.

Strength: The very orderly structure of the course made it run like a machine. Perfect execution on that front. Very transparent exams and very intriguing lectures. 

Weakness:Not much. Pretty air tight course.

Theres a whole lot of material covered in this course, which is necessary because there are so many metabolic processes. That also means that were not spending a lot of time on each process, which makes the class incredibly difficult.

It's a LOT of work and moves very very fast! You need to make sure you keep up! I learned a lot of interesting things, but you will probably need to put in 2x as much work as you initially think. It's well organized though and both profs are clearly amazing. 

At the end of every lecture, there's a 15 minute supplement. I wish the profs would have made the supplements available after because they were really interesting applications of the sometimes dense material.

As for the course itself, Prof Simon takes the first half, which I think is naturally easier, and Prof Koelle does the second, which goes by ridiculously fast. Each half has its unique challenges and you really need to be able to adjust quickly between the halves of the semester.

Also, beware: people are really smart in the course. Curve is harsh.

Protein biochemistry is super interesting, but when the course moves into the jumbled pathways and enzymes of metabolism I think it loses everyone. Also, memorizing the entire glycolytic pathway for a quiz worth 5% of your grade is a complete waste of time. At least the workload was very manageable.

Strengths:
(1) VERY well taught. (2) Problem sets were not difficult, but they were still comprehensive and provided a great review of the material. (3) Supplements were always very interesting and relevant. (4) Lectures were always logically-organized and easy to follow. (5) Section always provided useful reviews of what was covered in class. (6) Piazza was a valued resource, especially considering the amazing peer tutor for this course. (7) Division between first and second halves of this course was very well-done.


Weaknesses:
(1) Sometimes it felt like memorization was emphasized too much. I agree that memorization is very important for grasping larger concepts in biology, but sometimes it felt excessive and like we had to know literally EVERY detail of every lecture. (2) It would have been nice for difficult concepts like tandem MS and non-equilibrium steps to be given more care (tandem MS could have used more attention, though the blame partly falls on us students for not asking more questions when Professor Simon asked if we had any; non-equilibrium steps were explained pretty well with the pipe analogy, but emphasizing how critical this concept was and really pressing students to understand would have made learning about metabolism later on a bit easier).
Very well taught by Prof. Simon and Koelle. Lectures were great and always fun to attend. One suggestion would be maybe to include more application based or experimentation based content in lectures.

I think the work should perhaps be spread out a bit more throughout the semester. I also think the midterms are worth too much, and I think it's worth having a true third midterm to lower the amount of content present on each. The second midterm in particular covered a very large amount of content. Strengths were that I did feel like I learned biochemistry at a deep level. I now understand certain things (adrenaline signaling, hunger/starvation) in a way that helps me better understand how my body works. Weaknesses: this class being graded by percentiles can make it difficult to do as well as you want, especially given the intensity of many of those who take it. Overall, I enjoyed the class and learned a lot but think the grading was a bit harsh.

I have very mixed feelings about the supplements at the end of each lecture. I do think it was a little bit of a time-waster to spend 10 minutes each lecture learning about a random topic instead of, for example, learning the process of photosynthesis. I also think that since students were told from the very beginning that the supplements would not be tested, all students were extremely distracted and itching to leave. Perhaps if there was an extra credit question on an exam about one of the supplement topics, it would encourage students to stay and listen more.
On the other hand, I did think that the supplements brought the material to life. I learned about medicine and technology topics that I had never known before, which was very interesting. I just wish that somehow the supplements were better integrated into the material of the class, rather than small, separate lectures.

The last thing I wish was different was the test correction system of this course. I personally never appealed a question, but I did think some of the grading was inconsistent (some friends and I wrote virtually the same thing but got graded differently), and when people appealed for a grade change, rather than trying to help students learn why they were wrong, the grading staff were just adamant about not returning points without explaining why.
The course is well organized, and the exams were fair. The material was interesting. The supplements were really great, too! I enjoyed those a lot.

The course goes very indepth and throws a lot of fascinating information at you. THe class is weak in that it can be cut throat at times and seem very strict and harsh to do well. THe class is, however, one of the most interesting classes I have ever taken and I feel like such an expert on some topics at the end. The way we can talk and think about metabolism is incredible. I actually understand why some diseases like diabetes are so popular.

Strengths: Matt Simon is a great lecturer, clear and very engaging. 
Weaknesses: Later exams were unduly hard and not much support was given re: review sessions and otherwise.

I thought the instructors and TA's were strong and explained the material clearly. I thought there could have been more coordination between the two professors, and thought the explain-your-answer questions on the exams really punished students from straying from the precise answer key answer. Though this didn't happen to me, a friend who didn't do well on the first midterm was advised to drop the class rather than be offered support, and I thought this was an inappropriate response on  Prof. Simon's behalf.
This course presents a lot of information, but it is well structured to help students learn.

Strengths: Lectures are very good, Simon & Koelle are a good combo for teaching, content covered is very interesting

Weaknesses: Sections were not standardized and had varying degrees of usefulness, exams are graded fairly arbitrarily, doing well in the class requires a LOT of memorization, problems sets are near useless since they are so easy and not representative of exams
Well taught and organized, but felt rushed through material sometimes

I really enjoyed the lectures and I think the material is well selected to cover the most important aspects of biochemistry. However, the grading policies for this class seriously need to be improved. As a start, it would be nice if the whole psets were graded (I really don't think it would take the TAs more than 5min per pset) and if the expectations of the class were clear. You can't tell students not to worry about details and then ask about PTI as a trypsin inhibitor, which you spent barely a second on in lecture. Also, the average on the exams was lower than expected not because the exams are too hard or the students aren't smart enough, but because the grading of the exams is way too harsh, and for no good reason.
The course focuses way too much on memorization and not enough of understanding of key concepts. This is especially the case with the second half of the course.

Strength: tas are very knowledgable and helpful
Weakness: rote memorization
The course was structured in a way that allowed for new material to be easily woven into already learned concepts.

The teaching was really great, both professors did a great job and were very engaging.  There is a lot covered, but it is presented well. the weekly assignments were great and very fair.  Could be more transparent with the grading.  Unclear what the cutoffs are for different grade ranges.

This course is way too dense. It was too much material taught in too much detail with not enough time to learn it. There was also almost no support outside the classroom and my TA was terrible. It was not an environment that wanted you to succeed.

I thought this course was very well organized and taught. The two professors were outstanding in terms of their depth of knowledge and selection of interesting examples. I enjoyed the supplements at the end of lectures very much. I thought that I emerged from this course with a genuine and deep understanding of biochemical principles, particularly in regards to enzymes and metabolism. I thought that the expected prerequisite knowledge was reasonable, though I would have enjoyed greater connection to what I learned in organic chemistry. I appreciated the problem sets as an easy way to earn a few points, but I don't think I learned very much from doing them. Occasionally, grading on the homework was ambiguous because of vague questions and/or answers, and I rarely received explanations for lost points. I wish that the professors held regular office hours. 

I do not think that a cumulative final is appropriate for this class--the amount of material I had to review for that exam was positively overwhelming, and full comprehension and memory of all concepts taught in the course is probably impossible for most humans. (I say this as someone who scored in the top quintile on both midterms.) I think that having three equally weighted midterms each testing 1/3 of the course material would be a better way of assessing students and would certainly reduce stress and anxiety. That being said, I found the exams to be generally fair and well written, with two exceptions. First, I dislike the emphasis on memorization of facts for the fill-in-the-blank questions--I much prefer your in-depth concept questions such as the serpin question on the final, which was one of the best exam questions I've seen in Yale STEM. Second, I found it somewhat unfair to explicitly test Midterm 1 content on Midterm 2 (e.g., the silk question).

Overall, this was probably the most challenging STEM course I've taken so far at Yale, and it was also the most rewarding. I really enjoyed the class and its professors.
I really enjoyed this course. If anything, I thought the discussion sections could have been structured to be more helpful.

I really did feel like I was able to use all of my previous science knowledge in this course and I did feel that I was able to learn a very significant amount about protein dynamics and the human metabolism. I felt that the class offered useful knowledge that will be critical in medical school. The weaknesses are that my TA was very unhelpful and would frequently provide wrong or unhelpful answers, making section useless, and because homeworks were gimme points, a lot of the grade was based in very dense exams. The downfall of this is that a large portion of the exams are route memorization of facts.

Strengths: well organized, well taught
Weaknesses: a bit too detail-oriented at times

The strengths of this course are its outstanding professors (Prof. Simon and Prof. Koelle), its intuitive course structure, and the supplements that followed normal lecture. Lectures were easy to follow and provided a great deal of information that felt both relevant and exciting. One weakness of this course is that it does not include a lecture on photosynthesis, which I feel would provide a sense of the full cycle of energy in the biosphere.

Structure and organization are a strength. Weaknesses in setting expectations I think, as it's not always clear what instructors are looking for, and the emphasis on "applying principles" seems very false much of the time.

Exam questions could be improved. Often they seemed ambiguous and no partial credit was given for answers that clearly showed a comprehensive understanding but lacked a certain detail. 
Study guides were not very helpful

The lectures were generally very engaging and well-organized I liked how there were supplement lectures included to apply the concepts we were learning. I think the amount of support for students was also a strength Piazza, the peer tutors, etc. were all very helpful.
I felt that there was not very much support for students, and the exams were very challenging.

This is an excellent course in that it requires as little rote memorization and as much practical knowledge and interpretation of pathways of as possible so you can make sense of biochemical processes as a whole, not just the ones you learned.
The tests were graded very arbitrarily and the first half was way more engaging than the second (which was sad, given most of the more interesting stuff was in the second half)
Great material, not tested well.

I enjoyed the lectures and the supplements that the professors provided. I think that the exams were fair, because the answers to the questions were in the lecture slides, however some of the questions were very specific.

While this course packs a lot of material in a short amount of time, it does a good job of having low stress problem sets that aid out learning without taking much time. Further, the professors are VERY clear and explain complicated concepts systematically and in a really organized way.

I was not incredibly engaged with this course, even though I love the material. I wish my discussion section was more engaging and much smaller. It was too large for me to bother coming, because I didn't feel it was supplementing lectures. Lectures were great, a little dry at times, but overall engaging. Perhaps what I was craving was a deeper understanding of the material, rather than simply trying to memorize everything.

The course is very well designed to facilitate learning, and very engaging. I really enjoyed all the lectures, especially the supplements were a very good way to show the modern applications of the principles we learned.

The strengths of this course are the details that the course engages. The organization of the course allows for an understanding of broader concepts that help when it comes to learning the various pathways of metabolism. 

The weaknesses of the course include the weekly homework. The homework was at a level that did not prepare for the difficult exams. The homework should reflect more thought-provoking questions rather than simple "fill-in-the-blank" type questions.

Strengths:
-Overall the course was very, very well taught. Lectures were clear and 

-Many resources were provided to facilitate learning and individual studying. Practice exams were especially helpful, as well as answer keys to previous exams.

-In general lectures were well organized, study guides and lecture notes were provided for each 
lecture. 

-Piazza was extremely useful 

-Ben was the best peer tutor I've ever had


Weakness:
-Professor Koelle's lecture slides were sometimes a bit confusing, especially when trying to study from them after lecture.

-Professor Koelle's study guides were a times not super helpful as well. For example, they would often say, "You should understand..." without providing any explanation or overview with that topic. This ties in to the previous point, because some important material presented in the lecture slides was presented as a diagram or chart, which on its own is sometimes not super helpful. It would help if, at least somewhere some written explanation was provided. This was most evident for the Q cycle. One lecture slide just had a diagram with no words of explanation, and the study guide just said "Understand the Q cycle."

-Professor Koelle, if you're reading this, please, for the sake of all that is good and decent just use a normal, clear font on your slides.

This course could use instructor office hours, more heavily-weighted problem sets, and another midterm.

I also think that this course could use more practice questions.
Too much memorization that seems pointless.

This is a good course; they tell you pretty clearly what you need to know, psets are fair, test material, and are pretty easy to complete on time.  The professors should have regularly scheduled office hours.
The course's major weakness was that it seemed to be structured to prioritize brute memorization of the material.
Don't take it unless you have to. The grading system is terrible, the lectures are often done poorly, and some of the TAs are quite sub-par.

Probably have to take it, and it's definitely better than the MCDB version. Just be prepared to spend the time you would normally spend on psets for this class on studying the material. Psets are a breeze and just intended for you to review the material on a basic level. Tests, on the other hand, are super-specific and, because the class is full of pre-meds, very difficult to do well on without a crap-ton of preparation. I really wish this class hadn't been so all-or-nothing, because it made it difficult to enjoy the material and the learning process.

This course has a large workload and a massive amount of material to learn. That being said, it is very well taught and organized. Regardless, do not take this unless you really care about Biochemistry. Passing the class requires engaging with the material really well!
I would not recommend this course, instead I would recommend them to take the MCDB biochem class.
I would recomend this course for someone who is interested in biochemistry and organic chemistry.
I took it because I had to as a premed student. It's a super difficult class and I'm probably not going to do very well but a lot of it is my fault for not putting in the time that I should have.
no
I really found the biochemistry fascinating and do think the course was organized well. I would recommend this course to another student.

A great course, I'd definitely recommend it.  You have to memorize a ton of stuff, but I realized in hindsight that this led to me learning a lot.  The class does a fantastic job of comprehensively covering important topics in protein biochemistry and metabolism, and made me feel much more knowledgable/confident as a scientist.  Simon and Koelle are both great lecturers, and put a lot of thought into how they present material. 
 That being said, you have to be highly interested/invested in the material to enjoy it and it'll probably suck if you aren't.  The curve is pretty killer, and I spent a ton of time studying for exams, but it's a surprisingly little time commitment during the rest of the semester (weekly problem sets usually take like 20-30 minutes) so it's not a huge drain on your time.  Also GO TO SECTION, it's optional but you do practice problems that heavily resemble exam questions (sometimes they even pull test questions directly from the section problems).

you probably have to take biochem at some point. I don't regret picking this over MCDB biochem for a lot of reasons - this class was more consistent in workload (close to nothing, except when midterms came around), it went more in-depth as far as content (which is more interesting), and the lecture slides were well-prepared. That being said, studying for each of the midterms and the final is pretty heavy work (much like it is in other upper-level bio classes at Yale), so it's not all easy-peasy either.

Only take this course if it's required. The cutthroat environment makes it really unenjoyable to take, and it's incredibly competitive. The material is fine but the environment of the class makes it honestly awful.
Do not take this unless you have to.
It's fine. I took it instead of the MCDB version because I prefer more chemistry, and I definitely don't regret that decision, but it's huge drag of a class.
I would not recommend this class, but it is a required class for a lot of majors/ pre-med.

The class is well taught, well organized, and the untested supplements at the end of lecture are very interesting. Heads up though that exams will ask you to memorize an uncomfortable amount of detail (e.g. small details shown once in a relatively complicated figure on a slide), but nothing too unreasonable.

Premeds: consider taking physiological systems with this class. The two complement each other very well in content (a few topics overlap completely), and together they provide a very interesting and fulfilling semester -- as long as you're aware of the combined workload of these two individually work-intensive classes.

The course material is interesting, but it was a difficult class. Both professors are good lecturers. Although they say this class is not about memorizing, there are many things you will have to memorize and regurgitate in painful detail. It would have been nice to have formal content review sessions leading up to exams, rather than just office hours.
Yes. Take this instead of the MCDB one. You will learn more and its a better taught class.
The workload isn't bad but the exams are very difficult. Study a ton!! you won't know everything just because of the nature of the course but you can try to do well by memorizing as much as you can!

Always 100% this over the MCDB variety. But be forewarned: DO NOT MAKE THIS A CLASS ABOUT MEMORIZATION. You won't get anything out of the class if you simply take everything for granted and memorize the slides. Instead, integrate the topics together to tell a sort of story and the stuff you're supposed to 'memorize' will just naturally flow.

Biochem in the MB&B department is a fairly good course - the content is interesting, the lectures are generally well-presented, the supplements at the end of each lecture are fascinating (probably my favorite part of the course). However, the exams can be tough, especially on the short answer questions, where points can be taken off because you didn't answer the question "completely." That's not to say the grading is unfair, but can be hard to get all the points.

If you have to take it, then obviously take it. If you're very (VERY) interested in Biology and/or Chemistry, then you could take it, but that seems like an interest you could satisfy in some other way. It's a great course, but unless required, it seems like an unnecessary difficulty to subject oneself to.

This course truly embodies the idea "you get out of it as much as you put into it." Biochemistry was a lot of hard work, but I feel like my efforts paid off--I can't believe how much I've learned over a single semester.

As some general comments:
--Professor Simon and Professor Koelle are both so incredibly knowledgable. This course was extremely well-organized (!!!), and feedback was always prompt/helpful.
--The one feature that makes this course EXTRAORDINARY is the fact that the instructors print out lecture slides for EVERY SINGLE STUDENT EVERY SINGLE CLASS. I cannot stress this enough--Professor Simon and Professor Koelle make the effort to print out 150 copies of lecture slides for every single student every single class without fail. If this isn't dedication, I really don't know what is.

I would recommend this course to those who are required to take it. It is much too difficult to be just taken for fun unless you just really really love biochemistry and are good at it. I actually enjoyed the lectures and the professors are wonderful, but the tests were too dependent on memorization of specific details from the lecture slides and the grading was very questionable but strict. If you take this class, literally memorize every detail on every slide to succeed. The class is also filled with a lot of really studious premed people so you cannot count on a curve to save you. Granted, this class will fill your head with a ton of information about proteins in various metabolic pathways and how their functions are carried out and regulated. You will definitely learn a lot. But, your brain can be exploding with knowledge but you can still do poorly on the tests because of the strict detailed memorization requirements and really specific grading rubrics.
Yes, this is a great biochemistry class!

If you must, you must. It's a very well designed course that doesn't have much of a flaw. You learn a lot of information but it is pretty easy to follow along with. Just keep up with material. This is NOT the kind of class where information can be memorized the day before and brain dumped onto the exam paper. There are questions that really test your understanding of concepts. The Psets are easy--usually three questions. The midterms are fair. The final was a breeze. It's just about keeping up and knowing when to ask for help.

I would only take this class if you absolutely need to or already have a lot of background in biochemistry. I really dont think that a semester is sufficient enough to learn all of the material unless you have a considerable amount of time to devote to just this class.

It's a LOT of work and moves very very fast! You need to make sure you keep up! I learned a lot of interesting things, but you will probably need to put in 2x as much work as you initially think. It's well organized though and both profs are clearly amazing. 

At the end of every lecture, there's a 15 minute supplement. I wish the profs would have made the supplements available after because they were really interesting applications of the sometimes dense material.

As for the course itself, Prof Simon takes the first half, which I think is naturally easier, and Prof Koelle does the second, which goes by ridiculously fast. Each half has its unique challenges and you really need to be able to adjust quickly between the halves of the semester.

Also, beware: people are really smart in the course. Curve is harsh.

Yes, if you want a relatively easy MCDB core class with half a semester of engaging lectures about protein biochemistry and half a semester of less-engaging lectures about metabolism. Would have appreciated more emphasis on lab skills and primary literature instead of rote memorization, though.

This is quite possibly the best course I've taken at Yale so far. It's a marvelous introduction to a key field for biologists of all classes, and I highly recommend it to anyone with even a bit of interest. It's taught and organized very well and gives the information it gives in a very effective manner.

This class was a really good way of bridging my bio and chem classes together--no joke. Something I didn't enjoy in my bio classes was the representation of biological molecules as blobs or circles in figures (like a pathway, for example). Likewise, I didn't necessarily enjoy the nitty gritty of electron movements in organic chem. This class was an excellent balance of the two, and actually helped me in my research laboratory.
I'm glad I took this biochemistry course, but be sure to keep up with the material AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.

I would definitely recommend this class. It's a ton of memorizing, but you learn a lot and leave with a broad conceptual understanding of biochemistry and metabolism. The material aligns perfectly with the biochemistry material tested on the MCAT. The professors were also great and the information was well taught.

I would highly, highly recommend this to another student. This class just is so interesting and I cannot wait to learn more about this subject. I feel like I actually learned something so relevant to what I want to do in life.

The first half was good, second half definitely got complicated. I'm guessing you have to take a biochem if you're looking at this, so gonna compare it to MCDB biochem (from talking to friends in the other course): 
MBB has better lecturers--from what I heard, MCDB's lectures were more confusingly formatted and you kind of have to teach yourself. However, MCDB has 4 non-cumulative exams, none during finals, which would take some pressure off at the end.
I would definitely recommend this class to a premed who needs to take biochem or any MCDB, MBB, EEB or BME majors to better understand the fundamentals of their course of study.

Yes. I liked it and hope to continue taking MBB courses. The other biochem is easier due the the non-cumulative nature of the exams, though. The second midterm is harder material and the curve is tougher bc many people drop after the first midterm. Though this didn't happen to me, a friend who didn't do well on the first midterm was advised to drop the class rather than be offered support, and I thought this was an inappropriate response on  Prof. Simon's behalf.

The course is fascinating and very well-taught. The workload is surprisingly low -- the only work outside of studying for quizzes/exams is one really short and fairly straightforward problem set every week. With that being said, the exams are hard and do require a lot of studying, and even then it is hard to do well enough to stand out (read: get an A) because everyone in the class is so smart. Don't let that stop you from taking it, though, because the lectures are thorough and organized, the professors provide a lot of material that will help you study for the class, and stuff you learn about is extremely interesting.

Yes! do take this course if you're interested in biochemistry, or if you want a solid biochemistry foundation for other coursework, tests, or for research. Make sure to keep up with the course material!

Very interesting class for anyone interested in biochemistry. Simon and Koelle are both very good lecturers. One drawback to this class is the exam format, which requires too much memorization and is graded fairly arbitrarily. Otherwise, highly recommend.
Good and necessary cours for establishing biochemistry background

I sadly would not recommend this course, which is a real shame given how interesting the material is. I would encourage students not majoring in MBB to stick with the MCDB version, which seems to have much clearer and fairer grading policies.
Take this course if you either have to for the MB&B major or if you're interested in biochemistry research.
Only if you have to
Yes, excellent course for premedical students and others interested in biochemistry.

The teaching was really great, both professors did a great job and were very engaging.  The material is very interesting, so this class is very appealing for that reason.  It is a lot of material for sure, but it is presented well.  The weekly problems sets are not a lot of work at all, which is a nice break compared to a lot of other classes. You can easily do most of them in lass than an hour.   You just have to be on tp of learning stuff though because we do cover a lot. That means that that there is a lot of studying that needs to be done so this class then becomes a lot more work around exam times.  Almost the entire grade for the class comes from exams so be ready for that.  Lot of hardo premeds so everyone is trying to do well and many do so hard to keep up compared to everyone.
This course is terrible. Don't take it.

If you're deciding between MB&B and MCDB biochem, I would highly recommend this MB&B course. Although it is rigorous, you will learn the concepts extremely well from engaging and very knowledgeable professors. This course emphasis underlying principles and application of these principles to specific real-life examples, and the professors often connect these examples to real-life situations in "supplements" at the end of lectures. A challenging but incredible and rewarding introduction to the field of biochemistry.
Definitely take this class. The professors are great and you will learn a lot if you put the time in.

Yes I would recommend this course (if you are pre-med you have to take it and if your are a bio major in general you should). It really allowed you to utilize your previous science knowledge, the professors were very knowledgeable and committed to the class and to making sure that you learned the material.
Yes if you are interested in gaining a deeper understanding of biology on a more detailed level! The exams were fair, homework assignments not too much work.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student, especially if he/she is interested in learning about how biochemical processes translate to the functioning of living systems. Both Prof. Simon and Prof. Koelle are fantastic lecturers who clearly are passionate and knowledgeable about the subject.
Be prepared for memorization lol
Yes to all pre-medical students because it truly is a fascinating class and will prepare well for MCAT and Med School

If you need to take biochemistry as a prerequisite or are generally interested in biochemistry, I'd recommend the course. Although it's definitely a challenge and will take work to keep up with, the lectures are engaging and well-organized and there's a lot of help available to aid in understanding the material.
I would not recommend the course unless you have to take it for your major or premed or something. Still I would take the MCDB biochem if you have the option instead of this one.
Yes this is a fantastic course that teaches so much worthwhile information. Especially for premed

If you're taking it, you probably have to. It's not bad and you learn a lot, but the exams answer keys LITERALLY say, in some cases, "this answer is correct but receives no credit" so you need to read the professors minds. It's a little stressful and I have no idea what grade I'm going to receive for that reason which I don't think is the way it should be, but oh well I really like proteins so at least it was interesting and that's something.

I would recommend this course to another student, because the professors are great and really care about your learning. You do have to set aside time to study for this course to fully understand the concepts.

100% yes. As an MCDB major, I was debating which biochem to take and do not regret my decision one bit. I learned so much, and this class definitely had the best lecture professors Ive had thus far at Yale.

I would recommend this course because of the lectures-- often lectures about this material can be dry and unengaging, but most of the time they were quite interesting and built off of each other. The professors are extremely admirable and makes one want to learn from them.
The course is a great introduction to biochemistry. If you need to take biochemistry, definitely take this course. It is also really great and fundamental knowledge as a biology elective.

For any student who is not required to take this course but would still like to take biochemistry, I would recommend the MCDB equivalent course. The MBB course was very challenging and I found that the amount of work that I spent studying for the exams was not reflected in my grade. That would not be an issue if the rest of the class did poorly, but the distribution of grades seemed skewed due to MBB majors taking the course while already having an understanding of the concepts.
Yes. Though difficult it may be, this is a very, very well taught course and the instructors have it down to a science.

Absolutely not. You are taking this course because you have to for the major or for pre-med. And if you are taking this course because you simply want to, then you must be crazy. Have fun laboring over the intricacies of something that will immediately flee your mind upon the course's completion and be replaced by
I would. I really enjoyed the course and the instructors, but I found the exams very difficult.
No worst class at yale.
Only take it if you absolutely have to. So much memorization that feels pointless, lectures that feel endless and often boring.
Take it. The professors are good; its a bit dry because its biochemistry, but they try hard to make it engaging and are very clear about what they expect you to know.
I would only recommend to students who require it.
